claim: US Airways Flight 1549 had 1978 people on board.

supporting.text: US Airways Flight 1549 was an Airbus A320-214 with a maximum capacity of approximately 180 passengers and crew combined.

attacks.text: US Airways Flight 1549 was an Airbus A320-214 with a maximum capacity of approximately 180 passengers and crew combined.
The Airbus A320-232 variant has a maximum certified passenger capacity of up to 266 in single-class configuration.
Historical records show US Airways Flight 767 (not Flight ₁₅₄₉) operated with over two hundred passengers in its final flight.
The specific variant operated by US Airways on January ¹⁵th did not have single-class configurations exceeding its stated limits.
The FAA certification records explicitly list Airbus A3₂₀₋₂₁₄ as having maximum capacities below two hundred seats.

supporting.text: Official accident reports confirm there were only 155 people aboard (150 passengers + 5 crew) during the Hudson River landing.

attacks.text: Official accident reports confirm there were only 155 people aboard (150 passengers + 5 crew) during the Hudson River landing.
The official accident reports cited by A2 are not publicly accessible and may contain unverified data.
The passenger and crew count in A2 excludes non-registered individuals who might have been aboard.
A2 relies on a single source (NTSB) without cross-referencing airline manifests or other records.
Publicly available NTSB documents explicitly state the passenger and crew totals as part of their verified investigation.
Airline manifests from US Airways at the time of Flight 1549 corroborate the passenger count of 150 and crew of 5.
Multiple independent sources (e.g., news archives, survivor accounts) confirm the same passenger/crew numbers as A2.
The exclusion of non-registered individuals in A2 is irrelevant since only registered passengers and crew were aboard.
NTSB's methodology for counting occupants during emergencies is standardized and widely accepted in aviation investigations.
News archives from January 16, 2009 (the flight date) explicitly mention '150 passengers and five crew' in multiple reputable outlets.

supporting.text: The number '1978' exceeds typical commercial aircraft passenger limits and aligns with no credible historical records of this flight.

attacks.text: The number '1978' exceeds typical commercial aircraft passenger limits and aligns with no credible historical records of this flight.
The actual passenger count of US Airways Flight 1549 was 155 according to official aviation records.
The claim of '1978' passengers contradicts known data about the Airbus A320's maximum capacity of 180 passengers.
Official aviation records refer to different flights or contain errors in their documentation.
The number '155' is accurate for Flight 1549 but does not invalidate other potential data sources.
The Airbus A320 can carry up to 200 passengers under certain configurations such as reduced seat pitch.
Historical records may have been misinterpreted or misattributed to other flights.
The Airbus A320's standard capacity is confirmed at 180 passengers by manufacturer specifications.
The discrepancy in passenger counts likely stems from confusion with other incidents involving similar flight numbers.

supporting.text: No major news outlets or aviation databases list Flight 1549 as having over 1,000 people on board during its fateful journey.

attacks.text: No major news outlets or aviation databases list Flight 1549 as having over 1,000 people on board during its fateful journey.
The absence of mentions in major outlets does not prove the claim's falsity; it could indicate a lack of comprehensive reporting.
Aviation databases may not always be up-to-date or accurate, so their lack of data doesn't validate the claim.
Major news outlets typically verify critical details like passenger counts for high-profile incidents such as Flight 1549.
Aviation databases are authoritative sources for flight records and would reliably document passenger capacities.
News outlets often prioritize sensationalism over accuracy, making their omission of specific numbers less conclusive.
Database inaccuracies are rare for commercial flights with publicized incidents like Flight 1549.

supporting.text: The 'Miracle on the Hudson' incident involved a single aircraft with fewer than 200 occupants, contradicting claims of over 1,900 people.

attacks.text: The 'Miracle on the Hudson' incident involved a single aircraft with fewer than 200 occupants, contradicting claims of over 1,900 people.
US Airways Flight 1549 actually carried exactly 36 passengers and crew according to official aviation records.
The term 'occupants' in aviation terminology includes only registered passengers and cabin crew members.
Historical data shows Flight 1549 had only one engine failure rather than multiple incidents requiring larger crews.
Official FAA reports confirm Flight #1773 (not #1878) had exactly one pilot and one co-pilot aboard.
Aviation safety protocols require minimum crew sizes for commercial flights exceeding certain passenger counts.
The 'Miracle on the Hudson' occurred in January/February of different years according to primary sources.
